claims_summary: Army intelligence analyst leaked 750,000+ classified documents to WikiLeaks exposing Iraq/Afghanistan war crimes and diplomatic deceptions, convicted under Espionage Act, sentenced 35 years, commuted after 7 years

leaked_documents: 750,000+ classified documents: Iraq War logs, Afghan War documents, diplomatic cables
Collateral Murder video: Apache helicopter footage of Reuters journalists killing (2007)
Iraq War logs: 391,832 documents on military operations, civilian casualties
Afghan War documents: 91,731 reports on war operations, Pakistan ISI-Taliban ties
WikiLeaks publication: All documents published and publicly available
war_crimes_exposed: Collateral Murder: Video shows Reuters journalists killed, children wounded, crew laughing
Civilian casualties: War logs document systematic underreporting of deaths
Torture: Detainee abuse documented beyond Abu Ghraib revelations
Rules of engagement: Permissive ROE allowed civilian deaths
Helicopter strikes: Pattern of civilian targeting documented
diplomatic_cables_revelations: State Department internal communications: Gap between public and private positions
Intelligence operations: CIA activities revealed in embassy cables
Foreign leader assessments: Candid (unflattering) evaluations of allies
Corporate espionage: State Department gathering intelligence for businesses
Yemen drone strikes: Secret U.S. operations revealed
prosecution_and_imprisonment: Arrested May 2010: Adrian Lamo confession led to arrest
20 charges: Espionage Act violations, convicted August 2013
35-year sentence: Longest sentence for leak in U.S. history at time
Acquitted of 'aiding the enemy': Most serious charge dismissed
Obama commutation: January 2017 after 7 years served
Re-imprisonment 2019: Contempt for refusing Assange grand jury testimony
concealment_mechanisms: Overclassification: Documents classified to hide embarrassment not security threats
No public interest defense: Espionage Act prevents explaining why documents leaked
Secret grand jury: Assange investigation sealed from public
Media criticism: Some outlets attacked Manning rather than exposed crimes
Military justice: Court-martial limits transparency compared to civilian trial

validation_status: Extensively documented through leaked documents themselves, court-martial records, WikiLeaks publication, journalistic investigation of revealed war crimes
